module.p:
Common nouns are nouns which describe a class of entity and may be used to identify specific instances of that class, eg.
bean [fem.] woman
cànan [masc.] language
uisge [masc.] water
Common nouns contrast with proper nouns, which refer to particular, specific entities.
cf. generic quantity nouns.

Commons nouns can be divided into three groups, depending on how they are formed –
Derived common nouns are formed from other nouns, adjectives or verbs, typically by addition of a suffix eg. bàrd [masc.] poet → bàrdachd [fem.] poetry, Leòdhas [masc.] Lewis → Leòdhasach [masc.] man from Lewis, ceart [adj.] correct → ceartas [masc.] justice, seall [vb.] look → sealladh [masc.] view.
Compound common nouns are formed from other common nouns, typically by addition of a prefix eg. mùtaire [masc.] person engaged in an illegal activity, cùl [masc.] back, behind → cùl-mhùtaire [masc.] smuggler; aithris [fem.] report, recital, beul [masc.] mouth → beul-aithris [fem.] folklore.
Simple common nouns are not formed from other words eg. taigh [masc.] house, deoch [fem.] drink, cù [masc.] dog.

Like all nouns, common noun forms have number (singular or plural), gender (feminine or masculine) and case (nominative or dative or genitive), eg.
Leugh bean a’ mhinisteir leabhraichean anns an eaglais The minister’s wife read books in the church
bean woman, wife – singular, feminine, nominative
m(h)inisteir minister’s – singular, masculine, genitive
leabhraichean books – plural, nominative
eaglais church – singular, feminine, dative
The rules for declining common noun forms are as follows –

The dative singular form of a common noun is almost always identical to the corresponding nominative singular form eg.
taigh [masc.] house → taigh
balach [masc.] boy → balach
sùil [fem.] eye → sùil

However, feminine nouns ending in a broad consonant are often slenderised in the dative, particularly if they are preceed by the definite article eg.
làmh [fem.] hand → làimh
bròg [fem.] shoe → bròig
cailleach [fem.] old woman → caillich

Notes –
Slenderisation is sometimes accompanied by raising of the root vowel eg.
clach [fem.] stone → cloich
grian [fem.] sun → grèin
A few feminine common nouns have idiosyncratic traditional dative singular forms eg.
bean [fem.] woman → mnaoi
bò [fem.] cow → boin
brù [fem.] belly → broinn
sgian [fem.] knife → sgithinn
Nouns ending in -(e)achd are never slenderised eg. naidheachd [fem.] news, naomhachd [fem.] holiness.
In contemporary Gaelic usage, feminine dative common nouns are generally not slenderised unless they are preceded by the definite article eg. anns a’ chraoibh in the tree versus ann an craobh in a tree (cf. the traditional ann an craoibh).
External sources – gràmar-g

The genitive singular of most feminine common nouns is formed by slenderising the corresponding nominative singular (if possible) and adding the suffix -e eg.
craobh [fem.] tree → craoibhe
làmh [fem.] hand → làimhe
sgoil [fem.] school → sgoile

The genitive singular of most masculine common nouns is formed by slenderising the corresponding nominative singular (if possible) eg.
balach [masc.] boy → balaich
cat [masc.] cat → cait

However, some common nouns form their genitive singular by deslenderising the nominative singular (if possible) and adding the suffix -a eg.
sùil [fem.] eye → sùla
fiodh [masc.] wood → fiodha

Finally, bisyllabic feminine common nouns ending in -(a)ir usually form their genitive singulars in -r(e)ach eg.
obair [fem.] work → obrach
cathair [fem.] chair, city → cathrach
litir [fem.] letter → litreach

Notes –
Slenderisation is often accompanied by raising of the root vowel eg.
clach [fem.] stone → cloiche
bòrd [masc.] table → bùird.
Similarly, deslenderisation is often accompanied by lowering of the root vowel eg.
fuil [fem.] blood → fala
muir [masc.] sea → mara.
Common nouns ending in a vowel are usually unchanged in the genitive singular eg.
baile [masc.] town → baile
colaiste [fem.] college → colaiste
balla [masc.] wall → balla.
Nouns ending in -(e)achd are unchanged in the genitive eg.
naidheachd [fem.] news → naidheachd
beachd [masc.] opinion → beachd.
Recent loanwords from English are typically unchanged in the genitive eg. bus [masc.] bus → bus.
There are a few idiosyncratic genitive singular forms of common nouns –
athair [masc.] father → athar
bean [fem.] woman → mnatha (or mnà)
bò [fem.] cow → bà
bràthair [masc.] brother → bràthar
cù [masc.] dog → coin
leabaidh [fem.] bed → leapa
màthair [fem.] mother → màthar
piuthar [fem.] sister → peathar
taigh [masc.] house → taighe.
In contemporary Gaelic usage, polysyllabic feminine genitive common nouns are generally not augmented with -e eg.
uinneag [fem.] window → uinneig (cf. †uinneige)
aibideil [fem.] alphabet → aibideil (cf. †aibideile)
The nominative plural form of a common noun is coming soon.
The genitive plural form of a common noun is coming soon.

Like all nouns, a common noun can have a specifier, which is either –
a determiner as pre-specifier eg. an taigh the house, ar cù our dog
a (usually genitive) noun as post-specifier eg. taigh Sheumais James’ house, cù mo mhàthar my mother’s dog

A common noun which is a (post-)specifier of another noun is usually in the genitive case eg.
taigh a’ choin the dog’s house
taighean nan con the dogs’ houses

However, if it has a post-specifier itself, it is nominative eg.
taigh cù a’ mhinisteir the minister’s dog’s house
taighean coin a’ mhinisteir the minister’s dogs’ houses (cf. taighean c[h]on a’ mhinisteir)
taigh cù ministear a’ chlachain the village’s minister’s dog’s house
taighean coin ministear a’ chlachain the village’s minister’s dogs’ houses (cf. taighean c[h]on ministeir a’ chlachain)

A plural common noun which is the (post-)specifier of another common noun, but has no specifier itself, is lenited eg.
taighean bhanwomen’s houses

Like all nouns, a common noun can have one or more (post-)modifiers, which are either –
an adjective eg. taigh geal a white house, coin ruadha bheaga little ginger dogs
a genitive common noun eg. cù taighe a house dog, taigh chon a kennel (ie. dog house)
a prepositional phrase eg. caileag le falt fada a girl with long hair, na taighean agam my houses
a relative clause eg.
leabhar a sgrìobh mi a book which I wrote
uinneag nach do bhris iad a window which they did not break
balach leis an deach i dhan sgoil a boy who she went to school with.

A specified common noun can stand in apposition to a proper noun, agreeing for case (and number) eg. Dòmhnall an sagart Donald the priest [nominative case], le Dòmhnall an t-sagart with Donald the priest [dative case], taigh Dhòmhnaill an t-sagairt Donald the priest’s house [genitive case].

Some common nouns are inherently concrete, being normally associated with a material (tangible) sense, eg.
Tha taigh aig a’ mhinisteir The minister has a house
Dh’ith na coin an fheòil air a’ bhòrd The dogs ate the meat on the table

Other common nouns are inherently abstract, being normally associated with a non-material (intangible) sense, eg.
Is e cànanan clasaigeach a tha ann an Laideann agus anns a’ Ghreugais Latin and Greek are classical languages
Dh’ionnsaich Màiri eachdraidh anns an sgoil Mary learned history at school

However some common nouns can be either concrete or abstract depending on context, eg.
Tha Dòmhnall a’ sgrìobhadh leabhair Donald is writing a book – abstract
Tha Dòmhnall a’ sgrìobhadh ann an leabhar Donald is writing in a book – concrete

Some singular common noun forms are inherently countable, being associated with a bounded sense, eg.
Tha cù aig Raonaid Rachel has a dog – a (simple, bounded) individual
Tha treud air a’ mhonadh There is a herd on the moor – a (complex, bounded) group

Other singular common noun forms are inherently uncountable, being associated with a non-bounded sense, eg.
Tha Raonaid ag òl fìona Rachel is drinking wine – a (simple, non-bounded) substance (ie. a ‘mass’ noun)
Bha crodh air a’ mhonadh There were cattle on the moor – a (complex, non-bounded) aggregate (ie. a ‘collective’, noun)

However, some singular common nouns can be either countable or uncountable, depending on context, eg.
Tha ugh air an làr There is an egg on the floor
Tha ugh air feadh an làir There is egg all over the floor

Plural common nouns are usually associated with non-bounded, aggregate senses, eg.
Tha coin aig Mairead Margaret has dogs
Tha uighean air feadh an làir There are eggs all over the floor

However, as in English, there are some plurale tantum uses, where a plural noun is associated with a (simple, bounded) individual, eg.
Càite a bheil mo speuclairean? Where are my spectacles?
Note that some plurale tantum English nouns correspond to normal singular countable Gaelic nouns, eg. briogais (feminine singular) ~ trousers (plural).
cf. anthropic common nouns, toponymic common nouns, faunal common nouns
